2.text: A new telescope for mapping the sky is starting work at ESO’s Paranal Observatory in Chile

8.text: and has just released its first images.

11.text: It’s called VISTA, or the Visible and Infrared Survey Telescope for Astronomy,

16.text: and it’s the largest and most powerful infrared survey telescope ever built.

27.text: Cutting-edge science and life behind the scenes of ESO, the European Southern Observatory.

32.text: Exploring the universe’s ultimate frontier with our host Dr J, aka Dr Joe Liske.

42.text: Hello and welcome to another episode of the ESOcast.

45.text: Now even for an observatory like ESO, it’s a special occasion when a new telescope starts operations.

50.text: VISTA is the first survey telescope at ESO’s Paranal observatory and is dedicated to mapping the sky at infrared wavelengths.

58.text: It will chart the southern sky to much greater depth and with much greater sharpness than has ever been done before.

64.text: The first images have just been released and they clearly show that VISTA is working extremely well.

75.text: Interesting things found by VISTA will form targets for detailed study

80.text: both by the neighbouring ESO telescopes — such as the four eight-metre VLT unit telescopes —

86.text: and by other observatories on Earth and in space.

90.text: VISTA will find the rare needles in the cosmic haystack and then the VLT can study these needles in great detail

97.text: so astronomers can try to understand what they are and what’s going on in the Universe.

103.text: “VISTA was conceived in the UK about ten years ago.

106.text: A consortium got together to get it built and it has now become an ESO telescope as part of the UK’s contribution on joining ESO.”

114.text: VISTA has a main mirror that is 4.1 metres across,

118.text: which makes it the largest telescope in the world that is entirely dedicated to surveying the sky.

123.text: The mirror is also the most highly curved of its size and quality ever made,

127.text: and its construction was a major challenge.

130.text: The telescope is housed in a dome near ESO’s VLT on Cerro Paranal,

134.text: which means that it shares the top-quality observing conditions of that site.

141.text: At the heart of VISTA is a 3-tonne camera containing 16 special detectors

146.text: sensitive to infrared light, with a combined total of 67 megapixels.

152.text: This huge instrument provides the widest sky coverage of any astronomical near-infrared camera.

159.text: “VISTA is a telescope with an infrared camera and this allows us to look at the sky in a way that we can’t see with an optical camera.

167.text: Specifically, infrared cameras see preferentially cool objects

172.text: objects at a higher redshift, or indeed objects that are hidden behind dust clouds.”

177.text: VISTA is performing a total of six huge surveys over the next five years.

183.text: Some focus on small patches of sky for long periods to detect extremely faint and distant objects

189.text: and others image the entire southern sky.

193.text: The surveys study the distribution of galaxies and galaxy clusters,

197.text: help unravel the mysterious nature of dark matter and dark energy

201.text: and look for rare objects — all the way from tiny but dangerous near-Earth asteroids

207.text: out to the most remote quasars in the early Universe.

210.text: Our own Milky Way galaxy and its neighbours, the Magellanic Clouds, also receive their own surveys.

219.text: VISTA generates several hundred gigabytes worth of data every night of observing.

224.text: That’s about as much as all of the VLT instruments put together!

228.text: These data flow into ESO’s archive system at its headquarters in Germany

232.text: and they are sent on to the UK for further processing.

235.text: The first images show the power of the telescope to image large areas of the sky quickly and deeply.

246.text: One of the first VISTA images released shows the Flame Nebula,

250.text: a spectacular region of gas and dust where stars are being formed.

254.text: VISTA’s infrared eyes can see through the dust

257.text: and reveal the cluster of hot young stars in the heart of the cloud.

265.text: At the bottom of the wide VISTA field of view the ghostly form of the Horsehead nebula is faintly visible.

282.text: VISTA has also created a dramatic view in the direction of the centre of our Milky Way galaxy.

287.text: The wide field of view of the telescope and the highly sensitive infrared detectors of its camera

292.text: allow over one million stars to be seen, many normally hidden behind dust.

304.text: The Fornax cluster of galaxies is one of the nearest rich collections of galaxies.

309.text: VISTA’s large field allows many of the cluster’s galaxies to be imaged at once

314.text: including the elegant classical barred spiral galaxy NGC 1365 at the lower right.

321.text: This unique image shows several of VISTA’s impressive capabilities.

328.text: “VISTA’s users will be not only the European astronomers

331.text: who set up and specified these surveys in the first place,

335.text: but, because they’re public surveys, and the results will be available worldwide,

339.text: astronomers over the whole world will be using them to extract exciting results.

344.text: And, in many ways, history shows that the most exciting results that come out of things like this

349.text: are often what you least expect — obviously I don’t know what that is!”

353.text: VISTA will give astronomers an entirely new view of the southern sky

357.text: and we're all eagerly awaiting the results from this powerful new addition to ESO’s observational toolkit.

362.text: This is Dr J signing off for the ESOcast.

365.text: Join us again next time for another cosmic adventure.
